maml:description.maml:para: Copies one or more audio files to new files located on a file system drive.
The Copy-AudioFile cmdlet copies one or more audio files to a specified directory.
The new file name(s) and/or directory can be generated from metadata by specifying keys inside curly braces. For more information, type "Get-Help Copy-AudioFile -Examples".
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The audio file to be copied.
The new file name, without extension.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
The audio file to be copied.
The new file name, without extension.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The audio file to be copied.
The new file name, without extension.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command copies song.wav from the current directory to C:\Output\song.wav
This command copies song.wav from the current directory to C:\Output\copiedsong.wav
This command copies all the .flac files in the current directory to a new directory structure under C:\Output, using metadata to construct the directory structure and file names.

This command copies all the .flac files found anywhere under the Myself user's Music directory to a new directory structure under C:\Output, using metadata to construct the directory structure and file names.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or more audio files located on a file system drive.
The Get-AudioFile cmdlet gets one or more audio files in a specified directory. Relative paths and wildcards are supported.
For more complex operations, such as recursively searching through a directory tree, you can use Get-ChildItem and then pipe the results into Get-AudioFile.
Specifies a path to one or more files. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).

Specifies a path to one or more files. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
Specifies one or more files.
Specifies a path to one or more files. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
Specifies one or more files.

Specifies a path to one or more files. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an audio file named song.wav in the current directory.
This command gets all audio files with a .wav extension in the current directory.
This command gets all audio files with a .wav extension in the Myself user's Music directory.
This command recursively gets all audio files with a .wav extension in the Myself user's Music directory and all subfolders.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the audio information describing one or more audio files.
The Get-AudioInfo cmdlet simply returns the AudioInfo property for one or more audio files.
The audio file.
The audio file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the audio information for an audio file named song.wav in the current directory.
This command gets the audio information for all audio files with the .wav extension in the current directory.

maml:description.maml:para: Applies an analysis algorithm to one or more audio files.

The Measure-AudioFile cmdlet generates metadata about one or more audio files by examining the audio streams with the specified analyzer. Passing multiple audio files to a single cmdlet instance will treat them as a single album, or grouping. This cmdlet will never modify the audio itself.
To get a list of available analyzers, use the Get-AudioAnalyzerInfo cmdlet.
The results can be retrieved with the Get-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet, or by accessing the Metadata property directly. To persist the results to disk, use the Save-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet.
The name of the analyzer to use. To get a list of available analyzers, use the Get-AudioAnalyzerInfo cmdlet.
The audio file to be measured.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The name of the analyzer to use. To get a list of available analyzers, use the Get-AudioAnalyzerInfo cmdlet.
The audio file to be measured.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command applies ReplayGain 2.0 analysis to song.wav in the current directory.
This command applies ReplayGain 2.0 analysis to song.wav in the current directory, then returns the measured TrackPeak value.
This command applies ReplayGain 2.0 analysis to song.wav in the current directory, then persists the results to disk.
This command applies ReplayGain 2.0 analysis to all audio files with a *.flac extension in the current directory. The files are treated as a single album.

This command applies ReplayGain 2.0 analysis to all audio files with a *.flac extension found anywhere under the Myself user's Music directory. Each directory is processed as a separate album. Finally, the results are persisted to disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Renames one or more audio files on a file system drive.
The Rename-AudioFile cmdlet copies one or more audio files to a specified directory.
The new file name(s) can be generated from metadata by specifying keys inside curly braces. For more information, type "Get-Help Rename-AudioFile -Examples".
The new file name, without extension.
The audio file to be renamed.
Writes the renamed audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.
The audio file to be renamed.
Writes the renamed audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command renames song.wav in the current directory to renamed.wav.
This command renames song.wav in the current directory to a new name based on the TrackNumber and Title metadata values.

maml:description.maml:para: Encodes one or more audio files to new files located on a file system drive.
The Export-AudioFile cmdlet encodes one or more audio files using the specified encoder, and saves the resulting files in a specified directory.
To get a list of available encoders, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
The resulting file name(s) and/or directory can be generated from metadata by specifying keys inside curly braces. For more information, type "Get-Help Export-AudioFile -Examples".
The name of the encoder to use. To get a list of available encoders, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The audio file to be exported.
The new file name, without extension.
Encoder-specific settings to apply. To see the available and default settings for an encoder, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The name of the encoder to use. To get a list of available encoders, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
The audio file to be exported.
The new file name, without extension.
Encoder-specific settings to apply. To see the available and default settings for an encoder, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The name of the encoder to use. To get a list of available encoders, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
The audio file to be exported.
Encoder-specific settings to apply. To see the available and default settings for an encoder, use the Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports song.wav in the current directory to a new FLAC file with the same name, using default settings.
This command exports song.wav in the current directory to a new Wave file, replacing the original.
This command exports song.wav in the current directory to a new FLAC file with the same name, using compression level 8.
This command exports all the .flac files in the current directory to MP3 files under C:\Output, using metadata to construct the directory structure as well as the file names.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets detailed information about the available encoders.
The Get-AudioEncoderInfo cmdlet provides detailed information about the available encoders currently loaded by PowerShell Audio.
The name of the encoder. If not specified, all available encoders are returned.
The name of the encoder. If not specified, all available encoders are returned.
Gets detailed information about the available metadata encoders.
The Get-AudioMetadataEncoderInfo cmdlet provides detailed information about the available metadata encoders currently loaded by PowerShell Audio.
The audio file extension. If not specified, all available metadata encoders are returned.
The audio file extension. If not specified, all available metadata encoders are returned.
Gets detailed information about the available analyzers.
The Get-AudioAnalyzerInfo cmdlet provides detailed information about the available analyzers currently loaded by PowerShell Audio.
The name of the analyzer. If not specified, all available analyzers are returned.
The name of the analyzer. If not specified, all available analyzers are returned.
Saves CoverArt objects as image files.
The Export-AudioCoverArt cmdlet saves one or more cover art objects as image (JPEG or PNG) files.
The new file name, without extension.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The cover art to be exported.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Writes the cover art to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
The cover art to be exported.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Writes the cover art to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.

Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The cover art to be exported.
Writes the cover art to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports the cover art for song.wav in the current directory to a new file named Cover.jpg or Cover.png (depending on the image format).

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or more cover art files located on a file system drive.
The Get-AudioCoverArt cmdlet gets one or more cover art files in a specified directory. Relative paths and wildcards are supported.
For more complex operations, such as recursively searching through a directory tree, you can use Get-ChildItem and then pipe the results into Get-AudioCoverArt.
Specifies a path to one or more files. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).

Specifies a path to one or more files. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
Specifies one or more files.
Specifies a path to one or more files. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
Specifies one or more files.

Specifies a path to one or more files. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a cover art object from a file named Folder.jpg in the current directory.
This command gets the cover art for all audio files with the .jpg extension in the current directory.
This command gets the cover art for all audio files with the .jpg extension in the Myself user's Music directory.
This command recursively gets all cover art files with a .jpg extension in the Myself user's Music directory and all subfolders.

maml:description.maml:para: Clears the metadata on one or more audio files.
The Clear-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet clears metadata on one or more audio files. You can limit what is cleared by specifying one or more keys.
The name(s) of the metadata item(s) to be cleared. If not specified, all items are cleared.
To clear the cover art, specify "CoverArt".
The audio file that has the metadata to be cleared.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The name(s) of the metadata item(s) to be cleared. If not specified, all items are cleared.
To clear the cover art, specify "CoverArt".
The audio file that has the metadata to be cleared.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command clears the metadata on song.flac.
This command clears the metadata on song.flac and then persists the change to disk.
This command clears Genre and CoverArt metadata from song.flac.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts cover art to a different image size and/or format.
The Convert-AudioCoverArt cmdlet converts an existing CoverArt object into a image format. This can be used to limit image sizes on disk.
The cover art to be converted.
The maximum width, in pixels. If an image is wider than the specified value, it will be scaled to match the indicated value.
If specified, and the image is currently lossless (PNG format), it will be converted to lossy (JPEG). This usually results in significant space savings.
Specified the quality level, if the image is being converted to lossy (JPEG) format. The valid range is 0 to 100.
The cover art to be converted.
The maximum width, in pixels. If an image is wider than the specified value, it will be scaled to match the indicated value.
If specified, and the image is currently lossless (PNG format), it will be converted to lossy (JPEG). This usually results in significant space savings.
Specified the quality level, if the image is being converted to lossy (JPEG) format. The valid range is 0 to 100.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command converts Folder.jpg into a new image, resized (if necessary) to not exceed 600 pixels in width.
This command converts Folder.jpg into a new image, re-encoding it as a lossy JPEG image if it isn't already.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts an audio file's cover art to a different image size and/or format.
The Convert-AudioFileCoverArt cmdlet converts an audio file's CoverArt metadata into a new image format. This can be used to limit image sizes on disk.
The audio file that has the cover art to be converted.
The maximum width, in pixels. If an image is wider than the specified value, it will be scaled to match the indicated value.
If specified, and the image is currently lossless (PNG format), it will be converted to lossy (JPEG). This usually results in significant space savings.
Specified the quality level, if the image is being converted to lossy (JPEG) format. The valid range is 0 to 100.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The audio file that has the cover art to be converted.
The maximum width, in pixels. If an image is wider than the specified value, it will be scaled to match the indicated value.
If specified, and the image is currently lossless (PNG format), it will be converted to lossy (JPEG). This usually results in significant space savings.
Specified the quality level, if the image is being converted to lossy (JPEG) format. The valid range is 0 to 100.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command converts the cover art metadata on song.flac into a new image, resized (if necessary) to not exceed 600 pixels in width.
This command converts the cover art metadata on song.flac into a new image, re-encoding it as a lossy JPEG image if it isn't already.
This command converts the cover art metadata on song.flac into a new image, re-encodes it as a lossy JPEG image if it isn't already, and then persists the change to disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Saves the cover art for one or more audio files as image files.
The Export-AudioFileCoverArt cmdlet saves the cover art for one or more audio files as JPEG or PNG files.
The resulting file name(s) and/or directory can be generated from metadata by specifying keys inside curly braces. For more information, type "Get-Help Export-AudioFile -Examples".
The new file name, without extension.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The audio file that has the cover art to be exported.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Writes the audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.
The audio file that has the cover art to be exported.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Writes the audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The new file name, without extension.
Specifies a path to the output directory. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
The audio file that has the cover art to be exported.
If specified and the destination file already exists, it will be replaced. If not specified and the destination file already exists, an exception will be thrown.
Writes the audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies a path to the output directory. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters, enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any characters as escape sequences.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports the cover art for song.wav in the current directory to a new file named Cover.jpg or Cover.png (depending on the image format).

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the cover art for one or more audio files.
The Get-AudioCoverArt cmdlet simply returns the Metadata.CoverArt property for the audio files.
The audio file.
The audio file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the cover art for an audio file named song.flac in the current directory.
This command gets the cover art for all audio files with the .flac extension in the current directory.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets metadata ("tags") associated with one or more audio files.
The Get-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet returns metadata for one or more audio files. You can limit the results by specifying one or more keys.
The name(s) of the metadata item(s) to be included. If not specified, the whole metadata dictionary is returned.
The audio file.
The name(s) of the metadata item(s) to be included. If not specified, the whole metadata dictionary is returned.
The audio file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the title for an audio file named song.flac in the current directory.
This command gets the title and track number for an audio file named song.flac in the current directory.
This command gets the title for all audio files with the .flac extension in the current directory.

maml:description.maml:para: Persists changes or additions to one or more audio files' metadata to disk.
The Save-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet persists the current metadata to one or more audio files.
The audio file that has the metadata to be saved.
Encoder-specific settings to apply. To see the available and default settings for an encoder, use the Get-AudioMetadataEncoderInfo cmdlet.
Writes the audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The audio file that has the metadata to be saved.
Encoder-specific settings to apply. To see the available and default settings for an encoder, use the Get-AudioMetadataEncoderInfo cmdlet.
Writes the audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the title on song.flac to "Test Song" and then persists the change to disk.
This command updates song.mp3 with a new tag suitable for iTunes.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the cover art on one or more audio files.
The Set-AudioFileCoverArt cmdlet sets the cover art on one or more audio files.
The cover art.
The audio file upon which the cover art is to be set.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The cover art.
The audio file upon which the cover art is to be set.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the cover art on song.flac to the image from Folder.jpg in the current directory.
This command sets the cover art on song.flac to the image from Folder.jpg in the current directory, and then persists the change to disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the metadata on one or more audio files.
The Set-AudioFileMetadata cmdlet sets metadata on one or more audio files using HashTable syntax.
The metadata.
The audio file upon which the metadata is to be set.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
The metadata.
The audio file upon which the metadata is to be set.
Writes the modified audio file to the console. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the title on song.flac to "Test Song" and then persists the change to disk.
